I.

THE PROPOSAL

II.

INTRODUCTION

2.
The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  recommenced  lending  to  Cambodia  in  1992,  and
initially  focused  on  the  provision  of  emergency  generating  and  distribution  facilities  in  Phnom
Penh.1 This was followed by rehabilitation of the electricity systems in Phnom Penh and the two
important  provincial  towns  of  Sihanoukville  and  Siem  Reap.2  The  Project  will  (i)  expand  and
replace  the  inadequate  electricity  generation  and  distribution  systems  in  eight  additional
provincial  capital  towns,  thereby  removing  a  constraint  on  economic  growth  in  the  towns  and
rural hinterlands; and (ii) build the capacity of the Executing Agency, Electricité du Cambodge
(EDC),  to  provide  efficient  service  to  its  customers.  The  Project  is  included in  ADB’s  lending
program  for  2000  and  was  prepared  under  ADB  technical  assistance  (TA)3  completed  in
April 1998. Due to changes in political and economic circumstances in 1997 and 1998, the study
findings were updated under a small-scale TA.4 Loan appraisal5 was carried out from 20 July to
4 August 2000. This report is based on the findings of the TA reports and information provided
by the Ministry of Industry, Mines and Energy (MIME) and EDC. The project framework is given
in Appendix 1.

III.

BACKGROUND

A.

Sector Description

1. 

The Energy Sector

Cambodia is a predominately rural society emerging from a long period of conflict. With
3.
renewed  stability  and  steady  progress  on  reforms  to  gain  the  confidence  of  international  aid
agencies,  public  investment  should  be  sustained  at  levels  sufficient  to  stimulate  annual
economic growth of about 6.0–7.0 percent, which with population growth of about 2.5 percent,
translates into 3.5–4.5 percent per capita income growth. Agricultural productivity should begin
to  rise  with  priority  public  investments  in  rural  infrastructure,  and  growth  in  tourism  can  be
expected  in  selected  areas.  The  greatest  uncertainty  pertains  to  the  level  of  industrial  growth,
which depends largely on foreign investment. Gross value added in industry has grown robustly
in  the  last  three  years  (averaging  13.5  percent  per  year)  but  may  slow  in  the  short  term  as
garment  quotas  take  hold.  In  the  provincial  towns,  as  agricultural  productivity  and  per  capita
incomes  rise,  demand  for  electricity  from  residential  customers  and  small  enterprises  will
steadily increase.

 2

The  country  has  two  indigenous  sources  of  energy,  i.e.,  biomass,  which  provides
4.
85 percent  of  the  present  energy  consumption,  and  hydropower,  which  has  hardly  been
developed.  There  is  a  1  megawatt  (MW)  hydropower  plant  serving  Banlung,  the  capital  of
Rattanakiri Province, and a dam at Kirirom, which is all that remains serviceable of an 11 MW
hydropower  project  located  about  120  kilometers  (km)  west  of  Phnom  Penh.  The  balance  of
energy  demand  is  supplied  by  imported  petroleum  products.6  The  consumption  of  primary
energy  for  domestic  and  light  industry,  transport,  and  electricity  production  is  87  percent,
9 percent, and 4 percent.

5.
Imports  of  petroleum  products  in  1999  were  valued  at  approximately  $150  million  or
16 percent of total imports. This makes petroleum products the single largest import by value.
For  the  first  quarter  of  2000,  petroleum  product  imports  were  estimated  at  $45  million,
27 percent higher than the first quarter of 1999 and 19 percent of total imports. Clearly, rising oil
prices are increasing the burden of energy costs on the economy. However, this is not likely to
present  a  serious  balance  of  payments  problem  in  the  foreseeable  future.  Even  as  oil  prices
were  increasing,  international  reserves  have  been  rising  in  2000,  and  are  currently  over
$450 million  or  about  3.5  months  of  imports.  Moreover,  the  Government  has  had  a  quite
conservative macroeconomic policy over the last few years. The International Monetary Fund is
watching  the  balance  of  payments  position  closely  and  is  sufficiently  satisfied  with  its
management by Government to have recently released the second tranche of the facility under
a Poverty Reduction and Growth Facility program.

6.
The major energy source nationwide is fuelwood, which is used for cooking by most of
the  population,  and  almost  exclusively  by  the  rural  population.  Kerosene  is  used  by
nonelectrified  households  for  lighting,  mainly  in  the  countryside,  and  cooking  in  urban  areas.
The number of liquefied petroleum gas stoves is believed to be increasing in Phnom Penh, but
the  cost  of  gas  cylinders  and  new  stoves  is  an  impediment  to  widespread  proliferation  of  this
relatively  clean  fuel.  Liquefied  petroleum  gas  represents  only  about  0.2  percent  of  national
energy requirements.

2. 

The Electricity Subsector

a. 

General Structure

7.
The  electricity  sector,  never  more  than  rudimentary,  and  completely  destroyed  by  20
years  of  war,  is  making  progress  on  the  path  to  normality.  However,  the  obstacles  are
formidable. Responsibility for coordination of electricity sector policy and planning rests with the
Energy  General  Directorate  of  MIME.  Three  of  the  Energy  Departments  have  direct
responsibility  for  electricity  sector  planning,  i.e.,  the  Hydropower,  Solar  Photovoltaics,  and
Provincial Electricity departments. The latter formerly had operational responsibility for provision
of electricity in 17 provinces.

8.
Until recently, MIME has not had the resources to carry out its responsibilities to provide
an adequate electricity supply, with the result that its small (usually less than 200 kilowatt [kW]
generating  units)  are  often  inoperable  because  of  lack  of  spares.  Also  the  mismatched
distribution  components  are  overloaded,  and  fuel  is  not  always  available  due  to  payment
arrears. Private systems, which have grown on an ad hoc basis in many of the provincial towns,

suffer  the  same  problems  as  those  in  public  ownership.  As  there  are  no  administrative
restrictions for the private sector to participate in the supply of provincial power, entrepreneurs
who could provide a good quality of service are obviously not attracted to participate under the

tariff setting mechanism exists, and (iii) skilled operating staff are not available.

9.
Cambodia  has  no  national  grid  system;  electricity  supplies  that  do  exist  are  provided
either  by  self-generation  or  small  isolated  systems.  The  sector  can  be  divided  into  two  parts:
(i) Phnom Penh and seven towns supplied by EDC, and (ii) the remainder of the country.

b. 

The EDC Service Area

10.
As a result of dialogue with ADB and other development agencies, EDC was established
by  Royal  Decree  in  March  1996,  as  a  limited  liability  company  owned  jointly  by  MIME  and
Ministry of Economy and Finance (MEF). EDC has its own board of directors and operates with
considerable  independence  except  in  the  field  of  tariff  setting.  Its  charter  empowers  EDC  to
provide  a  nonexclusive,  full  electricity  service  for  the  whole  country.  Until  recently,  EDC  only
operated the isolated systems in Phnom Penh, and the urban areas of Kandal, Kompong Cham,
Siem  Reap,  and  Sihanoukville  but  during  2000,  it  took  over  the  operation  of  Takeo  and
Battambang  and  EDC  intends  to  gradually  fulfill  its  charter  obligations.  Meanwhile,  MIME
continues  to  be  responsible  for  all  other  areas.  EDC’s  organizational  structure  is  given  in
Appendix 2.

EDC’s  largest  system  is  in  Phnom  Penh,  which  has  a  population  of  about  1  million
11.
persons  in  168,000  households,  of  which  about  85,000  (51  percent)  have  an  electricity
connection.  The  system  in  Phnom  Penh  has  a  peak  demand  of  64  MW  and  a  generating
capacity of 90 MW, of which 35 MW is provided by a private power producer (PPP). A contract
with a second PPP was signed in 1996 under which 60 MW of additional capacity for the capital
was scheduled to come online at the end of 1998. After several delays, the World Bank group’s
International Finance Corporation withdrew its support for the Project in mid-2000; and it is now
doubtful  if  the  Project  will  proceed.  Therefore,  EDC  has  recently  entered  into  a  short-term
contract with a second PPP for 15 MW of diesel-fired generating capacity as an interim measure
to  meet  Phnom  Penh’s  demand  and  provide  sufficient  reserve  capacity.  Siem  Reap  and
Sihanoukville  have  about  3  MW  and  8  MW  respectively,  of  operational  diesel  generating
capacity, and the other areas served by EDC have a total capacity of about 6 MW.

12.
Partly, as a result of ADB loans and TA, the systems in Phnom Penh and the four other
towns  controlled  by  EDC  since  its  independence  are  well  managed,  and  customers  receive  a
much improved standard of service at an average tariff about 40 percent below those in most
provincial centers. Factors contributing to the improved performance are  (i) salaries have risen
with  the  result  that  qualified  staff  can  be  recruited  and  retained;  (ii)  tariffs  were  raised  by
40 percent  in  1999  (although  this  was  not  sufficient  to  produce  a  positive  operating  income);
(iii) sales growth has been strong, at least until the 1999 tariff increase; (iv) accounts are being
independently  audited;  and  (v)  EDC  has  recently  been  successful  in  breaking  an  electricity-
stealing racket that involved senior EDC staff.

13.
However,  EDC’s  financial  situation  remains  precarious  for  reasons  that  are  largely
outside  its  control.  For  instance,  its  loads  are  small,  and  can  only  reasonably  be  served  by

 4

diesel generating units that are inherently expensive to operate.7 With no economies of scale,
and with the necessity of maintaining a distribution system to serve a largely domestic market,
EDC’s average cost of supply is higher than the cost of self-generation by large and medium-
size  enterprises.  The  tariff  structure  provides  a  cross-subsidy  to  the  domestic  sector  from  the
commercial  and  industrial  sector  with  the  result  that  many  of  EDC’s  best  potential  customers
have turned to self generation (although the extent of the cross-subsidy has been reduced in the
current  schedule  of  tariffs).  Fifty  percent  of  EDC’s  costs  relate  to  fuel,  either  directly  or  as  a
pass-through  item  by  its  PPP  suppliers.  The  Government,  which  sets  tariffs,  has  not  allowed
tariffs  to  increase  sufficiently  to  keep  pace  with  rising  fuel  prices.  The  world  price  of  crude  oil
averaged about $13 per barrel in 1998, increased to an average of $18 per barrel in 1999, and
has  now  increased  to  over  $30  per  barrel.  In  Phnom Penh  and  Sihanoukville,  franchise  areas
formerly held by wholesalers8 have now been largely assumed by EDC, so that retail consumers
now  pay  for  their  consumption  at  EDC’s  scheduled  rates.  The  number  of  EDC’s  customers  in
Phnom Penh has increased from 21,000 in 1997 to 85,000 in 1999 due largely to its takeover of
wholesalers.  EDC  has  not  been  able  to  adequately  provide  meters  for  all  of  these  new
customers  or  to  include  them  in  its  billing  system,  thus  contributing  to  its  nontechnical  losses.
With  the  help  of  TA  from  Agence  Francaise  de  Developpement  (AFD)  of  France,  these
problems are currently being tackled.

c.

Outside EDC’s Service Area

14.
No  public  electricity  system  exists  for  most  of  the  country.  Wealthy  households  have
their  own  generators,  and  some  households  avail  of  battery  charging  services,  from  which
energy costs up to KR3,800 ($1) per kilowatt-hour (kWh). Most provincial capitals have a central
electricity system but all are inadequate in terms of capacity, safety, level of service, and cost.
The  distribution  systems,  which  generally  cover  only  the  central  parts  of  the  provincial  towns,
whose  populations  range  from  10,000  to  100,000,  are  mainly  owned  and  operated  by  MIME,
which either generates power or purchases power from private operators. Private operators with
capacity greater than 125 kilovolt-ampere (kVA) are required to be licensed by MIME, which has
offices  in  each  provincial  capital.  The  total  generating  capacity  nationwide  in  the  provincial
towns (other than those operated by EDC) is about 10 MW. Some towns have more than one
private generator, some of which also have a small, low voltage distribution system for up to a
few  hundred  households.  In  the  provincial  towns,  tariffs  are  controlled  by  an  arrangement
between MIME and the provincial governments. In each town, a single tariff is generally applied
to  all  consumers,  ranging  typically  between  KR960  ($0.25)  per  kWh  and  KR1,350  ($0.35)  per
kWh, with tariffs for some private power supplies up to KR1,600 ($0.41) per kWh. Losses in the
provincial  towns  are  typically  35  to  50  percent  of  units  generated.  These  figures  include
nonpayment  for  consumption  by  local  influential  people,  and  are  probably  not  sensitive  to
changes in electricity price. In spite of their present high tariffs, private producers have suffered
from  rising  fuel  prices,  and  where  further  tariff  increases  have  been  disallowed  by  the
authorities, a number of operators have ceased production.

B. 

Government Policies and Plans

1. 

Scope

In  October  1994,  Cambodia  formulated  an  energy  sector  development  policy  with
15.

affordable  prices,  (ii)  ensure  a  reliable,  secure  electricity  supply  at  prices  that  facilitate
investment  in  Cambodia  and  develop  the  national  economy,  (iii) encourage  exploration  of
indigenous energy resources leading to environmentally and socially acceptable development of
resources needed to supply all sectors of the Cambodian economy, and (iv) encourage efficient
use of energy and minimize detrimental environmental effects resulting from energy supply and
use. To implement the policy as it relates to the power sector, in January 1999, the Government
published its Power Sector Strategy for the period up to 2016. The strategy is described under
the headings of generation and transmission, private sector participation, regulatory framework,
commercialization,  provincial  and  rural  electrification,  and  the  environment.  As  such,  it
represents a road map of how to achieve the sector objectives. However, the strategy does not
mention  the  constraints  that  must  be  addressed  in  other  areas  if  the  objectives  are  to  be
achieved, such as governance and a weak legal and judicial system.

2. 

Generation and Transmission

16.

3. 

Private Sector Participation in Power Projects

19.
Recent Government involvement in the sector was dictated by the desperate situation of
the Cambodian electricity system in 1993. Because the Government could not afford the power
supply  infrastructure  required  to  meet  even  the  most  urgent  needs  of  the  country,  the
Government  accepted  proposals  from  investors  who  approached  with  turnkey  projects.
Accordingly,  four  power  purchase  agreements  (PPAs)  were  negotiated  to  meet  the  country’s
urgent power demand, although only two projects have been brought to commercial operation,

investment climate has improved in a number of ways, e.g., security has improved; laws have
been  promulgated  in  many  fields,  especially  regarding  investments;  and  the  democratic
framework  is  stronger.  At  the  international  level,  major  positive  signals  have  been  delivered
such  as  the  award  of  most  favored  trading  nation  status  to  the  Kingdom  by  the  United  States
and  admission  to  the  Association  of  South  East  Asian  Nations.  At  the  provincial  level,  the
Project’s capacity building components will improve the market environment in the provinces so
that private investors will be attracted to provide future system expansion.

20.
Under  the  energy  sector  policy,  the  Government  will  follow  a  new  approach  for  the
development and approval of private investment projects in the power sector, including (i) use of
a  transparent  process  to  select  independent  power  producer  (IPP)  developers,  using
competitive  tendering  procedures  for  all  significant  power  projects;  (ii)  use  of  a  termination
clause  in  PPAs  for  possible  transfer  of  assets  to  EDC  provided  the  utility  is  able  to  provide
supply at lower cost through the national grid, when it is established; (iii) introduction of a two-
part  tariff  for  the  purchase  of  electricity  from  IPPs;  and  (iv)  evaluation  of  all  private  sector
funding and ownership of significant power projects against public funding and ownership, and
joint ventures between the public and private sector. Contrary to the energy sector policy, both
the  rehabilitation  of  the  Kirirom  Hydropower  Project  and  a  small  franchise  to  import  and
distribute power in the province of Koh Kong were awarded by direct negotiation. Guidelines on
private investment and procedures for negotiating PPAs are the subject of policy dialogue with
ADB  and  other  development  partners.  ADB  agrees  with  the  Government  that  no  economies
would be gained by restructuring and privatizing EDC at the present time since its systems are
so small (90 MW in Phnom Penh and a total of 17 MW elsewhere).

4. 

Regulatory Framework

21.
Through  Royal  Decree  in  March  1996,  the  Government  announced  a  decision  to
establish an independent regulatory agency to improve the efficiency and availability of electric
power services in Cambodia by increasing private ownership and competition in electric power
generation.  MIME,  supported  by  World  Bank  assistance,  drafted  an  electricity  law  that  is
currently  being  considered  by  the  National  Assembly.9  The  law  will  create  the  electricity
authority  of  Cambodia  (EAC)  as  an  independent  regulatory  authority  and  also  establish  the
principles  on  which  all  operators  will  be  licensed  to  undertake  various  activities  in  the  electric
power  industry.  The  law  will  provide  the  basis  for  the  regulation  of  supply  of  electric  power
services  to  the  extent  such  services  are  monopolistic,  and  the  basis  for  the  protection  of  the
rights  of  consumers.  From  the  time  of  enactment  of  the  electricity  law,  the  EAC  will  be
responsible  for  approving  all  tariffs  and  charges  for  the  supply  of  electricity.  The  EAC  will
regularly  review  the  tariffs  and  charges  to  ensure  an  electricity  supply  at  reasonable  prices
consistent  with  providing  an  adequate  return  to  investors.  The  EAC  will  be  responsible  for
regulation of both private and public suppliers of electricity, including EDC.

6. 

Provincial and Rural Electrification

23.
Efforts have concentrated on bringing the electricity supply up to a reasonable standard
in the capital and two important commercial towns. To a large extent, this has been achieved,
and  the  Government  has  a  program  to  rehabilitate  the  electricity  systems  in  the  remaining
provincial capitals. Approximately, $90 million will be required in the medium term to rehabilitate
the remaining provincial capitals. The Government plans to seek concessional funds and private
sector participation, including public-private partnerships. Rehabilitation of the provincial power
systems  is  essential  for  the  proper  functioning  of  local  government,  and  to  stimulate  the  local
economies with positive impacts on the urban poor and the rural hinterland, thereby slowing the
migration of people to Phnom Penh.

24.
The  Government  also  has  a  strategy  for  rural  electrification  for  which  $10  million  per
year  for  10  years  has  been  estimated  as  the  minimum  capital  requirement.  Although  stand-
alone systems, particularly renewable generation such as microhydro, may be options in some
locations,  generally  the  most  viable  method  will  be  grid  extensions  either  from  suitable
substations  close  to  the  border  in  neighboring  countries,  or  from  the  grids  in  the  newly
rehabilitated  provincial  towns.  The  World  Bank  is  currently  providing  TA  to  prepare  a  staged
rural  electrification  strategy  and  a  10-year  program  to  increase  electricity  access  to  rural
communities.  Preliminary  findings  indicate  that  grid  extension  from  provincial  towns  will  prove
competitive compared with new generation facilities. The Project will therefore be a catalyst for
electrification of the surrounding rural areas.

7. 

Environmental Policy and Legislation in Cambodia

The Environmental Protection and Natural Resources Management Law, 1996, provides
25.
for all projects to be subject to an environmental examination. The law provides for the Ministry
of Environment to establish an environmental steering committee and project review teams for
different  sectors.  MIME  and  EDC  participate  in  both  the  steering  committee  and  also  the
relevant  review  team.  Government  policy  provides  for  sound  environmental  management  of
power  projects  through  a  systematic  approach  to  protection  against  pollution  of  air,  soil,  and
water;  protection  against  noise,  vibration,  and  radiation;  and  protection  of  flora  and  fauna  in
relation  to  power  sector  operations.  As  a  result  of  ADB  TA  2723,11  a  subdecree  on
environmental  impact  assessment  was  approved  by  the  Government  in  August  1999.
Guidelines for environmental impact assessments for thermal power and transmission projects
were also drawn up. The environmental requirements will be integrated into the development of
all power projects.

E.

ADB’s Sector Strategy

38.
The  country  operational  strategy  for  Cambodia  identifies  support  for  energy  sector
development as a key component of an overall strategy to enhance the enabling environment
for private sector participation in the economy leading to growth and poverty reduction. Private
investors identify high energy costs as one of the constraints inhibiting exploitation of business
opportunities  in  Cambodia.  Having  provided  emergency  aid  to  electrify  Phnom  Penh,  ADB’s
strategy has been to help the Government implement its power sector policy to satisfy demand
for  power  where  and  when  required.  Due  to  constraints  on  financial  and  human  resources,
priorities  have  been  set  for  which  areas  will  benefit,  starting  with  Phnom  Penh;  then
Sihanoukville,  the  main  port;  Siem  Reap,  the  main  tourist  destination;  followed  by  provincial
towns  and  rural  electrification.  ADB  has  made  a  major  contribution  to  rehabilitate  and  expand
services  in  Phnom  Penh,  Siem  Reap,  and  Sihanoukville  with  resulting  improvements  in

ADB’s  strategy  is  to  first  of  all  establish  reliable  and  efficient  systems  in  selected  provincial

IV. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT

A. 

Rationale

44.
The country needs a reliable, affordable, and efficient electricity supply as a fundamental
input  for  economic  growth  leading  to  poverty  reduction.  Substantial  improvement  of  the  living
standards of the rural poor is closely linked with economic development in urban centers. The
expected  benefits  of  rural  development  can  be  realized  only  if  farmers  are  able  to  sell  their
increased agricultural produce in the urban economy in exchange for such items as new farming
equipment,  fertilizer,  seeds,  technology,  and  better  consumer  goods.  Rural  development,
therefore,  is  correlated  to  the  absorptive  capacity  of  the  urban  economy  for  increased  rural
produce.  The  provincial  towns  in  the  country  serve  as  the  economic  centers  for  the  rural
hinterland.  In  the  provinces,  these  towns  are  the  immediate  markets,  transport  depots,  and
processing  centers  for  provincial  agricultural  products.  Improving  urban  services,  including
electricity  supplies  in  the  provincial  towns  will  therefore  contribute  to  poverty  reduction  in  both
rural  and  urban  areas.  Adequate  electricity  systems  are  absent  from  the  whole  of  the  country
with the exceptions of Kompong Cham, Phnom Penh, Siem Reap, and Sihanoukville.

45.
In  the  other  provinces,  the  owners,  both  MIME  and  the  private  sector  operators,  have
neither the capital nor the creditworthiness to fund rehabilitation, expansion, or upgrading of the
systems. The existing high tariffs demonstrate a willingness to pay for even an inferior supply,
and  surveys  conducted  under  the  project  preparatory  TA  show  that  improved  and  extended
services  will  attract  new  customers.  The  Project  will  rehabilitate  and  expand  the  electricity
generating  and  distribution  systems  in  selected  provincial  capitals,  and  train  staff  in  their
operation, maintenance, and management. The resulting systems will (i) provide a 24-hour per
day supply of high reliability and acceptable loss levels,17 (ii) reduce average tariffs in the project
towns, and (iii) allow for future system expansion. Two of the selected towns, Kampot and Svay
Rieng,  are  included  in  ADB’s  Provincial  Towns  Improvement  Project,18  which  will  also  provide

rehabilitated under ADB loan 1345 (footnote 2).

46.
No legal or administrative barriers exist for private sector participation in public electricity
supply, but virtually all private producers to date are extremely low caliber, very small scale, and
using  second-hand  equipment.  Public  safety  is  an  issue  in  power  supply  and  internationally
acceptable  standards  should  be  maintained.  Without  external  intervention,  the  needed
improvements in electricity supply are unlikely to materialize. At this early stage of Cambodia’s
development,  provision  of  basic  infrastructure  (even  revenue  generating)  cannot  be  left  to  the
private sector alone. Therefore, concessional funding is required. The Project will be owned and
operated,  at  least  initially  by  EDC,  which  will  receive  sufficient  help  with  human  resource
development to enable efficient operation of the systems. EDC has a record of taking over and
managing  systems  of  similar  size  and  larger,  decreasing  losses,  and  improving  accounts
receivable and customer service. ADB is aware that public ownership may not be the best long-
term  situation,  and  ongoing  TA  3453  (footnote  10)  will  identify  a  wide  range  of  possible

B. 

Objectives and Scope

47.
The  long-term  objective  of  the  Project  is  to  stimulate  economic  growth  and  thereby
reduce  urban  poverty  in  the  selected  provincial  towns  and  the  surrounding  rural  populations,
with the longer term goal of creating the enabling environment for private sector participation in
future  power  system  expansion.  Appendix  4  gives  information  on  the  selected  towns.  The
immediate purposes of the Project are to (i) expand the availability of reliable power supplies in
eight  provincial  towns;  (ii)  build  capacity  by  creating  suitable  management,  operation,  and
maintenance  organizations  in  the  provincial  centers  so  the  new  systems  are  efficient  and
financially viable; (iii) strengthen the skills in the EDC head office (which will remain responsible
for  over  90  percent  of  EDC  sales);  (iv)  expand  the  scope  of  training  available  at  EDC’s  ADB-
funded training center in Phnom Penh; and (v) setup a data-gathering system on which to base
future  hydropower  development.  The  scope  comprises  two  parts:    Part  A,  Infrastructure;  and
Part B, Capacity Building.

C. 

Technical Justification

57. With  the  exception  of  Banlung  and  Kampot,  the  generating  equipment  is  in  a  state  of
severe  disrepair,  kept  in  operation  only  by  the  mechanical  ingenuity  of  the  operators.  In  the
interests of safety and economy, it must be replaced. Banlung is served by a 1 MW hydropower
plant consisting of 2x500 kW turbine generators, with a storage reservoir to ensure dry season
firm capacity of 300 kW. This plant provides the sole supply for the town, although the two main
industries (rubber processing and wood products) have their own standby generators. The study
completed  under  the  project  preparation  TA,  found  no  economic  method  to  enhance  the  firm
capacity of the hydropower plant.

58.
For  the  study  towns,  no  realistic  alternatives  to  diesel  power  stations  currently  exist.
Theoretically,  a  number  of  other  forms  of  power  generation  are  possible,  but  they  are  more
expensive  than  diesel  engines.  Alternative  generating  options  investigated  include  the  use  of
renewable  energies  such  as  biomass-fired  power  plants,  wind  energy  converters,  solar  power
generation,  and  minihydro.  All  other  types  of  power  generation  conceivable  for  Cambodia
involve  central  power  stations  from  which  electricity  would  be  supplied  to  the  various  towns
through  transmission  lines.  Due  to  the  comparatively  low  electricity  consumption  in  the  towns
studied, the high capital costs of the necessary transmission lines cannot be justified.

1. 

Environment

The  major  physical  component  of  the  Project  is  to  rehabilitate  electricity  facilities  in
82.
selected  provincial  towns.  The  rehabilitation  will  include  replacement  of  old  distribution
equipment  and  facilities  such  as  transformers,  installation  of  small-size  diesel  generating  sets
(250-500 kW range), and improvement of medium and low voltage distribution systems. These
major  components  are  expected  to  have  only  small  environmental  impacts,  and  the  other
components of the Project, i.e., those related to capacity building, have no or minimal adverse
impacts on the environment. Consultants for the ADB-financed TAs 2629 (footnote 3) and 3256
(footnote  4)  conducted  an  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  for  the  Government  and
executing  agency.  Based  on  the  IEE,  no  environmental  impact  assessment  is  needed  for  the
Project. The Project is classified as Environment Category B, and the summary IEE is attached
as Appendix 10.

Environmental impacts associated with the construction of access roads, power stations,
83.
substations,  etc.  are  expected  to  be  small,  and  consist  of  dust  and  noise  during  construction,
and a risk of fuel oil spillage during operation. The new generators will be equipped with exhaust
gas  silencers  to  reduce  noise  levels  to  below  100  decibels  at  the  plant  and  40  decibels  at  a
distance  of  200  meters.  Provided  maintenance  schedules  are  adhered  to,  this  level  will  be
maintained for the life of the plant. Concerning air pollution, the diesel engines will be specified
to  conform  to  accepted  international  standards  for  maximum  concentrations  of  carbon
monoxide,  nitrogen  oxide,  and  particulates.  As  part  of  the  turnkey  contract,  operators  will
receive training by the manufacturers on monitoring emissions and taking corrective measures,
if  they  are  required.  Noise  and  air  pollution  caused  by  the  new  generators  will  remain
substantially  below  the  levels  from  the  existing  plants.  The  rehabilitation  of  the  distribution
facilities  may  cause  minor  environmental  impacts.  However,  sufficient  precautions  and
mitigation measures will be taken. In particular, when old transformers are replaced, the oil will
be  tested  for  the  presence  of  toxic  polychlorinated  biphenyl  (PCB).  If  PCBs  are  present,
disposal will be done in a strictly controlled and acceptable way such as incineration at a very
high  temperature.  Transformer  oil  containing  PCBs  must  be  thermally  destroyed  at  a
temperature above 1,300 degrees Celsius. As such an incinerator is not available in Cambodia,
PCB-contaminated  transformer  oil  will  be  transported  in  appropriate  containers,  either  to  a
cement factory in Cambodia where it can be burned in the kiln or to a neighboring country with
suitable  facilities.  In  the  former  case,  the  kiln  temperature  should  be  maintained  above  1,300
degrees Celsius at all times while the oil is being burned, and in the latter case, the oil should be
exported  in  accordance  with  the  provisions  of  the  Basel  Convention.  Provided  that  all  the
mitigation measures are implemented as specified in the IEE report, the adverse environmental
impacts  will  be  reduced  to  a  minimal  level.  An  environment  unit  established  in  EDC  will  be
responsible for implementing and monitoring the environmental management plan.

V. 

PROJECT JUSTIFICATION

A. 

Economic and Financial Analyses

1. 

Subproject Selection

89.
The  eight  project  towns  were  selected  from  a  longer  list  of  candidates  based  on
quantitative  and  qualitative  criteria.  The  criteria  were  accessibility  and  the  prevailing  security
situation,  existence  of  conditions  favorable  to  economic  growth  and  job  creation,  proportion  of
existing  population  engaged  in  nonagricultural  employment,  cost  per  kW  of  new  installed
capacity,  cost  per  consumer  connection,  environmental  impact,  comments  of  potential
stakeholders,  and  benefits  for  ethnic  minorities.  In  terms  of  development  potential,  the  towns
were ranked in descending order as follows: Sisophon, Kampong Speu, Kampot, Svay Rieng,
Takeo, Prey Veng, Banlung, and Stung Treng.

2. 

Load Forecast

90.
The  load  forecast  is  fundamental  to  project  planning.  The  load  growth  in  the  project
towns  is  one  of  the  major  decisive  factors  for  generation,  transmission,  and  distribution
planning,  and  therefore  has  a  decisive  impact  on  the  investment  costs  required  for  the
rehabilitation of the power systems in each town. Load forecast also has a major impact on the
economic  and  financial  feasibility  of  these  investments.  Details  of  the  load  forecast  are
described in Appendix 11, and are summarized in this section. The load forecast is based on a
model that forecasts sales in three consumer categories: residential, commercial and industrial,
and public offices and schools.

91.
The residential consumer group is the largest, and accounts for about 70 percent of total
sales in most towns. The Project will replace the distribution systems in the towns and extend
service  to  outlying  communities  around  each  town  within  1  or  2  km.  The  total  number  of
residential  consumers  will  increase  by  about  20  percent  as  a  result  of  rehabilitation  and
extension of the distribution systems. In addition, the number of customers will increase due to
population growth; and  sales per customer will increase due to income growth and to relief of
supply-side constraints, currently a problem in many towns. Separate forecasts were prepared
for  each town. Commercial  and industrial sales are typically about 20 percent of total sales in
the  provincial  towns,  and  are  forecast  to  grow  about  9-10  percent  annually  due  to  general
economic  growth.  Sales  for  public  sector  offices,  buildings,  and  street  lighting  constitute  the
balance of about 10 percent of sales. Sales will grow with general economic growth, and a one-
time increase when the Project is commissioned due to improved street lighting. Total electricity
sales are expected to increase by about 133 percent from 1999 until 2004, the first full year of
project operation, and by about 10.7 percent annually thereafter.

92.
The increase in total generation required when the Project is commissioned will be less,
due to the sharp reduction in distribution losses, from an average 46 percent at present to about
18 percent after rehabilitation. The high current levels of losses are based on statistics on total
generation  and  sales  in  1999.  The  forecast  losses  after  rehabilitation  are  based  on  actual
experience in the towns of Sihanoukville and Siem Riep, which were rehabilitated in 1998 under
the  first  ADB-financed  Power  Rehabilitation  Project,  and  where  average  losses  in  1999  after
rehabilitation were reduced to about 18 percent. In 2004, when the Project begins operation, the
total  generation  demand  in  the  eight  towns  covered  by  the  Project  is  expected  to  be  about
18,100 MWh, with a peak annual load of about 5.6 MW. This is about 54 percent higher than
total generation in 1999.

 28

3. 

Least Cost Analysis

93.
The plans for development and expansion of power supplies under this Project include
complete  replacement  of  the  distribution  systems  in  seven  of  the  eight  towns,  and  the
construction of new diesel power plants or transmission interconnections to larger grid systems.
At present all of these towns are isolated from any interconnected grid. The distribution systems
are generally in very poor condition. Voltage levels of the medium voltage distribution lines are
too  low  for  modern  utility  designs,  and  will  all  be  upgraded  and  standardized  at  22  kV  for  the
new systems. Distribution losses are very high, typically about 35-50 percent. The only practical
way  to  reduce  losses  and  to  serve  future  growth  is  to  replace  these  old  distribution  systems
completely  and  implement  new  management  systems.  Only  Banlung  has  a  satisfactory
distribution system, which just needs expansion.

94.
For isolated power systems of this size, the least costly form of independent bulk power
supply  is  diesel  power  generation.  Transmission  interconnections  with  larger  power  systems
were  also  considered  wherever  feasible.  Kompong  Speu  will  be  interconnected  with  Phnom
Penh. For Takeo, a transmission interconnection with Phnom Penh was considered but it would
be  too  costly.  For  Svay  Rieng,  a  22  kV  transmission  interconnection  to  Viet  Nam  is  the  least
cost source of bulk power supply. For Sisophon, the recommended least cost plan is to supply
load  growth  with  diesel  generation  initially,  and  then  to  connect  this  town  later  to  a  planned
115 kV transmission interconnection with Thailand. After this interconnection is commissioned,
the diesel generating units can be moved to another town.

4. 

Economic and Financial Evaluation

95.
For the economic analysis, the economic benefits of the Project are divided into two parts.
The first is the cost saving due to replacing the old and inefficient current power supply systems in
the  towns.  The  second  is  the  benefit  of  additional  electricity  sales  arising  from  the  Project.  The
cost saving due to replacing the current power systems is based on the tariffs that are currently
charged  in  each  town.  These  tariffs  are  just  adequate  to  cover  their  operating  costs,  but
depreciation is either neglected or very minimal, and interest charges are always ignored.

Residential  consumers  use  electricity  primarily  for  lighting,  and  to  a  lesser  extent  for
96.
television,  radios,  fans,  and  other  electrical  appliances.  However,  electricity  is  not  used  for
cooking,  since  it  is  much  more  costly  than  firewood  or  kerosene.  The  additional  electricity
consumption for residential consumers is valued on the basis of the average willingness to pay for
electricity based on a demand versus price curve that was derived from data for various towns in
Cambodia. The resulting average economic benefit of residential consumption is estimated to be
$0.35 per kWh.

Commercial and small industrial consumers, and public buildings, which account for about
97.
30 percent of total energy sales in provincial towns, use electricity for lighting, refrigeration and air-
conditioning, mechanical drives, and other applications. In the absence of public electricity supply,
small diesel generator sets are used to meet their power requirements. The weighted average of
current tariffs and alternative economic costs of self-generation is estimated to be $0.26 per kWh
in economic prices.

98.
The economic evaluation of each of the eight towns included in the Project is described in
Appendix  11.  The  overall  Project  has  an  estimated  economic  internal  rate  of  return  of
17.8 percent for the base case. However, the economic evaluation of benefits is conservative, as
no attempt was made to evaluate the benefits of improved reliability and quality of power supply,

 29

and cost savings to many individual consumers who require standby private generating sets now
to ensure reliable power.

99.
Sensitivity  analysis  indicates  that  the  economic  performance  of  the  Project  is  robust  for
moderate  increases  in  fuel  costs  or  capital  costs.  The  Project  can  tolerate  a  large  increase  in
crude  oil  price  up  to  $44  per  barrel,  at  which  point  the  economic  internal  rate  of  return  (EIRR)
reduces  to  a  marginal  12  percent.  The  project  economics  are  most  sensitive  to  reductions  in
estimated unit benefits or in total energy sales. The Project would switch to becoming uneconomic
if average benefit rates for new sales were reduced more than 30 percent, based on a minimum
12 percent EIRR.

100.
The financial evaluation is based on the financial revenues from electricity sales from the
Project, starting in 2004. It is assumed that tariffs will be adjusted as shown in Appendix 11. The
average planned tariff, three years after project commissioning, will be about 24 percent lower
than the existing average tariff, at year 2000 price levels. The average financial internal rate of
return  (FIRR)  for  the  overall  Project  is  estimated  to  be  4.2  percent,  just  enough  to  meet  the
weighted average cost of capital to EDC for the project financing of 4.1 percent. Therefore, the
FIRR for this Project is satisfactory.

B. 

Impact on Poverty

101. After  two  decades  of  civil  unrest  and  conflict  in  the  1970s  and  1980s,  poverty  is
pervasive  in  Cambodia.  In  1999,  the  Government  estimated  the  poverty  line  at  KR240,000
($62.52)  per  month  per  household  (consisting  of  an  average  of  5.3  persons),  i.e.,  $0.39  per
person per day for the urban areas other than Phnom Penh. This was the income required to
buy food of an average energy intake of 2,100 calories per person per day and a minimum of
nonfood items, and is well below the international standard of $1 per person per day. According
to  the  1999  national  census,  the  average  monthly  household  income  in  Cambodia  was
KR484,000,  equivalent  to  $126.  Appendix  12  (Table  A12.1)  shows  the  average  household
income by sector of employment in the project areas.

102.
The  average  monthly  household  income  in  the  eight  towns  ranges  from  KR322,000  to
KR597,000  (equivalent  to  $0.51  to  $0.97  per  person  per  day).  Within  each  town  and
employment  sector,  income  levels  vary  widely  but  about  30  percent  of  the  population  in  the
project  towns  are  living  below  the  poverty  line.  This  is  not  significantly  different  from  the
proportion nationally. However, Table A12.2 in Appendix 12 shows that the incidence of poverty
in Sisophon and Prey Veng is significantly higher than the national average, so that the Project
will have a poverty reduction impact in these towns.

103.
In the project towns, the present electricity tariffs range from KR800 ($0.21) to KR1,600
($0.41)  per  kWh  apart  from  Banlung  where  the  tariff  is  between  KR200  ($0.05)  and  KR400
($0.10)  per  kWh  (footnote  21).  Given  an  average  monthly  household  income  of  KR450,000  in
the  project  urban  districts  and  an  average  residential  household  consumption  of  25  kWh,  the
affordability ratio, i.e., the proportion of household income spent on electricity as a percentage
of  total  income  is  5.6  percent,  which  is  comparable  to  other  countries  at  a  similar  level  of
development. However, the many households living close to the poverty line are clearly unable
to  afford  even  the  average  consumption  level.  Nevertheless,  the  quality  of  light  from  a  10  W
fluorescent lamp is so superior to alternative wicklamps, that even poor people are anxious to
be  connected.  If  a  supply  is  not  available,  many  are  prepared  to  use  car  batteries  from  which
energy costs up to $1 per kWh. Poor people are just able to afford one or two 10 W lamps plus
a small black and white television set, which in total consume 8-10 kWh per month. Even at the

 30

very  high  prices  being  charged  in  many  areas  and  with  an  affordability  ratio  of  5  percent,
households  with  an  income  as  low  as  KR150,000  per  month  ($40),  i.e.,  $0.24  per  person  per
day, and well below the poverty line could obtain the benefits of an electricity supply if it were
available.  Extended  coverage  and  average  lower  tariffs  resulting  from  the  Project  will  make
electricity  more  affordable  to  a  greater  number  of  poor  households.  To  assist  new  customers
with the initial cost of connection, EDC will offer to construct and own the meter and the service
connection line for new residential consumers, and will recover this cost through an additional
monthly charge.

104. Without  doubt,  almost  every  household  strives  for  an  electricity  supply  to  facilitate
children’s  study,  and  via  television,  reduce  people’s  isolation  and  make  them  aware  of
opportunities  and  their  own  potential,  as  well  as  directly  lengthening  the  productive  hours  of
cottage  industries.  An  affordable,  reliable,  electricity  supply  has  an  almost  direct  impact  on
poverty,  as  defined  by  ADB,22  by  providing  a  direct  means  to  enable  users  to  sustain
themselves by their labor, and through information services become empowered to participate
in making the decisions that shape their lives.

C. 

Risks

105.
The  Project  is  technically  simple  and  straightforward,  and  given  EDC’s  record  on
previous  loans,  the  risk  of  serious  cost  overruns  or  implementation  delays  on  the  physical
infrastructure are considered small. There are risks with the economic outcome of the Project if
load  demand  does  not  increase  as  forecast  due  to  such  factors  as  political  instability  or
economic  recession.  This  risk  has  been  reduced  by  designing  the  Project  to  provide  new
generating  capacity  to  meet  anticipated  load  growth  for  three  years  after  commissioning,  i.e,
2004-2006,  at  which  time,  further  investment  will  be  required.  This  approach  has  limited  the
value of assets that will not be fully utilized if demand does not increase as rapidly as expected.
Economic viability could also be compromised if loss reductions and efficiency improvements do
not  materialize  as  expected.  Anticipated  improvements  are  based  on  actual  performance  of
EDC's  systems  at  Sihanoukville  and  Siem  Reap.  With  the  additional  years  of  operating
experience  by  the  date  of  commissioning,  EDC  should  exceed  the  expected  improvement
levels.

106.
The economic analysis has been based on an estimated crude oil price of $20 per barrel
in  2004,  which  is  slightly  higher  than  the  latest  World  Bank  forecast.  With  higher  fuel  prices,
tariffs  can  be  raised  to  maintain  EDC’s  income  at  a  level  to  meet  the  financial  covenants,  but
with  the  risk  that  tariffs  become  unaffordable  to  poorer  consumers  and  that  demand  in  all
sectors  will  be  reduced.  However,  the  Project  will  become  uneconomic  if  crude  oil  prices  rise
above about $44 per barrel.

There  is  a  risk  that  the  capacity  building  components  will  not  fully  achieve  their
107.
objectives.  Their  success  depends  on  recruiting  suitable  staff,  motivating  them  to  learn  new
skills, and retaining them within the organization for a suitable period after training. EDC, as an
independent company, is able to set attractive remuneration levels that up to now have enabled
it  to  retain  suitable  staff.  If  suitable  candidates  are  not  available  from  within  the  country,  then
recruitment from outside is possible.

Kompong  Speu  is  the  capital  of  Kompong  Speu  province  and  is  located  about  48  km

telecommunication  office,  two  health  centers,  nine  schools,  and  a  large  market.  Most

SUMMARY INITIAL ENVIRONMENTAL EXAMINATION

A. 

Introduction

The  initial  environmental  examination  (IEE)  of  the  Project  was  carried  out  by  the
1.
consultants under the Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed technical assistance (TA) 2629
and  3256  with the  assistance  of  the  Ministry  of  Industry,  Mines  and  Energy  (MIME)  and
Electricité du Cambodge (EDC), the Executing Agency of the Project. The major component of
the  Project,  which  involves  expansion  and  rehabilitation  of  old  electricity  facilities  in  eight
provincial  towns,  has  some  adverse  environmental  impacts.  The  capacity  building  component
has  no  adverse  impacts  on  the  environment.  An  environment  specialist  from  ADB  visited
Cambodia from 22 to 28 July 2000 and inspected a selection of the project sites and the central
workshop  of  EDC  with  the  officials  concerned.  The  Project  as  a  whole  is  classified  as
Environment Category B.

B. 

Description of the Project

2.
The Project consists of two components: (i) power system expansion and rehabilitation
in  eight  provincial  towns,  and  (ii)  capacity  building.  The  detailed  description  of  the  Project  is
given in Chapter IV of the main text.

C. 

Description of the Environment

1. 

Physical and Ecological Resources

3.
The Cambodian plain, where six of the eight project sites are located, is entirely flat in
the  areas  drained  by  the  Tonle  Sap  and  Mekong  rivers,  changing  only  in  the  north  eastern,
north western, and south western fringes to gently rolling to mountainous country. Sisophon is
located  in  the  hill  country  to  the  west  of  Tonle  Sap  Lake.  The  Tonle  Sap  River  fills  the  lake
during  the  rainy  season  and  drains  it  in  dry  season.  The  Cambodian  central  plain  is  mostly
inundated during the rainy season. The soil in the central plain consists mainly of highly fertile
silts,  and  clay  loams  in  some  areas,  which  are  suitable  for  low  land  rice  production.  In  the
highlands around Banlung, rice production is supplemented by upland crops such as maize and
a variety of vegetables.

4.
As the distribution, transmission, and generation sites are either in urban or semi-urban
areas or along roads with mainly rice fields on either side, the Project's impacts on ecological
resources,  such  as  forest  biodiversity,  habitat,  and  vulnerable  species,  are  found  to  be
negligible.

Although  urban  administrations  in  the  eight  project  areas  are  making  great  efforts  to
5.
improve  sewage  disposal  and  treatment  facilities,  their  efforts  are  hampered  by  budgetary
constraints, and sewage disposal remains critical. Drinking water supply is particularly critical in
most of the urban centers, as piped water is in short supply and most households rely on dug
wells and surface water as their main source of drinking water.

2.

Human and Economic Development

The population in the project areas is estimated at about 300,000 or 2.5 percent of the
6.
total population of Cambodia. In the provincial centers, a household comprises on average 5.3
persons.  The  population  pyramid  in  the  eight  urban  centers,  as  a  reflection  of  the  war,  shows

 65

Appendix 10, page 2

that the number of those aged 20-30 years has been greatly diminished. Also as a result of the
war,  the  proportion  of  displaced  persons  continues  to  be  high  causing  a  number  of  problems
both for provincial budgets and the labor market.

The economic infrastructure in all eight urban centers has been greatly affected by the
7.
war, and economic recovery is hampered by a lack of investment. After a period of slow growth
in the two previous years, the Cambodian economy grew by about 4 percent in 1999. According
to  the  population  census,  agriculture  is  the  most  important  sector  of  employment  in  all  of  the
eight  urban  centers.  Most  households  in  the  eight  towns  use  kerosene  for  lighting,  with  the
exception of Banlung, Kampot, and Svay Rieng, where electricity is the main source of lighting,
while  batteries  and  other  sources  account  for  3-5  percent  of  household  energy  supply.
A majority of households in the project areas use firewood as their main fuel for cooking and a
small percentage use charcoal.

8.
In  the  project  area,  health  and  sanitation  conditions  are  generally  poor  and,  therefore,
very  sensitive  to  adverse  environmental  impacts.  In  all  of  the  eight  urban  centers,  need  to
rehabilitate  not  only  the  electric  power  system  but  also  all  other  public  services  is  urgent,  as
progress in rehabilitating the sewage, water supply, education, transport, and health systems is
very slow. Reliable and affordable electricity supplies are essential for attracting business to the
provincial  centers,  which  in  turn  would  improve  the  employment  situation  and  strengthen  the
impetus for economic recovery.

D. 

Screening of Potential Environmental Impacts and Mitigation Measures

1. 

Preconstruction Stage

9.
Environmental  impacts  related  to  project  layout,  land  use,  construction,  operation  and
maintenance  are  considered  as  insignificant.  The  standard  layout  for  a  power  plant  with  a
maximum  capacity  of  500  kilowatt  (kW)  involves  a  power  house  with  a  control  room  and
workshop, a fuel storage and water storage facility, a 22 kilovolt (kV) substation, a warehouse,
an  office,  and  an  extension  area,  altogether  requiring  a  total  area  of  0.8-1.2  hectares  (ha).
Project  design  will  include  the  replacement  of  existing  transformers.  A  major  environmental
impact  can  be  expected  if  the  transformers  contain  polychlorinated  bi-phenyl  (PCB),  which  is
hazardous  to  human  health.  As the  existing  transformers  were  originally  supplied  from  the
former Soviet Union, they likely contain PCBs, and special handling procedures are, therefore,
required. Part A of the Project should be carefully designed and thoroughly examined to ensure
adverse environmental impacts are minimized.

10. 
The  sites  for  the  new  power  stations  and  substations  have  mostly  been  selected.
In some cases such as Kompong Speu and Takeo, the existing power stations will be sites for
new  facilities,  which  do  not  require  any  acquisition  of  land.  In  other  cases,  land  has  to  be
acquired. The land requirement for the diesel power plants varies from 12,000 square meters for
Sisophon to about 8,000 square meters for the smaller plants.

Appropriate measures should be taken to mitigate adverse impacts on land use, water
11.
resources, and the ecology. To mitigate the impact on land use, compensation payments will be
needed.  The  draft  electricity  law,  which  is  before  the  Council  of  Ministers  and  remains  to  be
ratified by Parliament, stipulates in Article 51 that a licensee may install, over any land, electrical
facilities and equipment necessary to satisfy electrical power supply. The draft law also requires
that the licensee take reasonable commercial effort to acquire rights of entry, rights of way, and
easements  through  negotiations  with  the  landowners  by  paying  appropriate  compensation.

 66

Appendix 10, page 3

Should  the  licensee  fail  to  obtain  such  rights  the  Electricity  Authority  of  Cambodia  (EAC)  may
certify the acquisition to be in the public interest to enable the relevant Government authority to
proceed with the compulsory acquisition of the easement or land for the licensee.

2.

Construction Stage

12.
The  main  problem  related  to  the  construction  of  access  roads,  power  stations,  poles,
and  substations  is  the  clearing  of  vegetation.  There  may  also  be  temporary  interference  with
existing  electricity  supply  or  traffic  flow  during  construction.  Other  impacts  such  as  dust  and
noise during construction will be minimal.

13.
Transport  and  storage  of  fuel  involves  several  potentially  adverse  environmental
impacts,  as  oil  can  leak  or  spill  into  the  subsoil  due  to  accident  or  mere  neglect.  Without
appropriate  safeguards  during  construction  as  well  as  operation,  oil  spills  or  leakages  may
pollute surface and groundwater resources.

Environmental  protection  standards  require  that  used  oils  with  PCB  content  exceeding
14.
20 milligrams/kilogram (mg/kg) and halogen content exceeding 2 grams/kilogram (g/kg) cannot
be processed but must be thermally destroyed in a suitably equipped incinerator. Normally only
hazardous  waste  incinerators  would  be  considered  as  suitable  for  destruction  of  PCB-
contaminated  transformer  oil,  and  since  there  are  no  such  incinerators  in  Cambodia,  PCB-
contaminated  transformer  oil  may  have  to  be  transported  to  a  neighboring  country  with
appropriate  facilities.  Another  option,  which  would  not  necessitate  the  transportation  of  PCB
contaminated oil to a neighboring country, would require directing contaminated transformer oil
to  energy  utilization  as  a  secondary  fuel  in  Cambodian  cement  works.  However,  this  option
would only be feasible if the cement work could guarantee the destruction of the PCB pollutants
by combustion at temperatures over 1,300 degrees Celsius. Due to its potential hazard for the
environment, other processing methods of PCB-contaminated transformer oil are discouraged,
even though they may be cheaper than the options discussed.

3.

Operation Stage

The main problems due to project operation are noise from diesel generators, emission
15.
of  air  pollutants,  and  hazards  associated  with  fuel  handling  and  power  distribution.  The  noise
impact from operating diesel generators will be reduced to acceptable levels by an appropriate
design of the powerhouse and by introducing exhaust gas silencers. Therefore, even if a school
is  in  close  proximity  of  the  power  station,  as  in  the  case  of  Sisophon,  the  noise  level  of  the
diesel  generator  is  not  expected  to  exceed  40  decibels  (dB)  at  200  m  distance,  assuming  a
standard  noise  emission  of  100  dB.  Since  the  noise  emissions  in  existing  power  stations  are
considerable,  introducing  new  generation  units  that  comply  with  international  noise  standards
will be a major improvement. The noise impact from operating diesel generators will be reduced
to acceptable levels by appropriate specifications for noise level and power house design.

16.
Air  pollution  due  to  generator  operation  mainly  involves  the  emission  of  carbon
monoxide, nitrogen dioxide, and particulates. Emission intensity varies according to the make,
age  and  maintenance  level  of  the  generator.  Nitrogen  dioxide  and  dust  pollutants  represent  a
health hazard, as they can cause irritations of the respiratory tract that can be dangerous if the
exposure is prolonged.

for standard compression ignition engines of a maximum concentration of 0.65 g/m3 for carbon

power plants need to be trained to ensure that emissions are regularly measured and emission

Load Forecast

The load forecast is fundamental to project planning and justification. The load growth in
1.
the  different  provincial  towns  is  one  of  the  major  decisive  factors  for  the  generation,
transmission,  and  distribution  expansion  planning,  and  therefore  has  a  decisive  impact  on  the

major impact on the economic and financial feasibility of these investments.

2.
The preparation of a reliable load forecast for each of the eight provincial towns in this
Project  was  difficult  in  several  cases,  due  to  the  impact  of  supply-side  constraints  on  historic
records  of  power  generation  and  sales,  and  the  unreliable  nature  and  limited  period  of  these
records. However, historic data on sales and generation was available for several towns, such
as  Kampot  and  Takeo,  where  supply-side  constraints  and  self-generation  are  not  significant.
The  sales  records  in  these  towns  were  used  as  a  basis  for  estimating  average  consumption
rates in other towns that have had supply-side constraints.

3.
The  revised  final  forecast  is  based  on  a  model  that  forecasts  sales  in  three  consumer
categories: residential, commercial and industrial, and public offices and schools. Table A11.1
shows  the  detailed  load  forecast  for  the  town  of  Kampot  as  an  example.  The  residential
consumer  group  is  the  largest,  and  accounts  for  about  70  to  80  percent  of  total  sales  in  most
towns.  The  Project  will  replace  the  complete  distribution  systems  in  the  towns,  and  extend
service  to  outlying  communities  around  each  town  (these  extensions  could  be  up  to  two
kilometers).  The  total  number  of  residential  consumers  is  estimated  to  increase  by  15  to
20 percent as a result of the rehabilitation and extension of the distribution systems. In addition,
the number of customers will increase due to urban population growth of about 2.8 to 3 percent
annually; and sales per customer will increase about 6 percent annually due to income growth.
Commercial  and  industrial  sales  are  typically  about  15  to  20  percent  of  total  sales  in  the
provincial towns. Sales to commercial and industrial consumers are forecast to increase about
9 to  10  percent  annually,  based  on  a  forecast  growth  rate  in  economic  activities  of  about
7 percent  annually,  and  an  energy  (electricity  demand)  elasticity  factor  of  1.3  to  1.4  against
economic  growth.  Sales  for  public  sector  offices,  buildings,  and  street  lighting  constitute  the
balance of about 10 percent of sales. Total sales will increase sharply by about 25 percent when
the  Project  is  commissioned  in  2003-2004,  due  to  the  increase  in  number  of  residential
consumers  and  improved  street  lighting,  and  thereafter  are  forecast  to  increase  at  about
10.5 percent annually.

4.
However, the increase in total generation required when the Project is commissioned will
be much less due to the sharp reduction in losses from 45 percent at present, to a rate of about

generation  required  when  the  Project  is  commissioned.  The  high  current  levels  of  losses  are
based  on  statistics  on  actual  total  generation  and  sales  in  1999.  The  forecast  losses  after

which were rehabilitated in 1998 under the first Asian Development Bank (ADB)-financed power
project,1  and  where  average  losses  in  1999  after  rehabilitation  were  reduced  to  about
18 percent. The forecast growth rate of peak loads after 2004 is slightly lower than the forecast

Least Cost Analysis

2.
The  plans  for  development  and  expansion  of  the  power  supply  in  each  town  covered
under  this  Project,  except  for  Banlung,  include  complete  replacement  of  the  distribution
systems,  and  the  installation  and  commissioning  of  new  diesel  generating  capacity,  or
transmission interconnections to a larger grid system. At present all of these towns are isolated
from any interconnected grid.

3.
Distribution  systems  are  generally  in  very  poor  condition,  having  been  almost  entirely
destroyed during the war and replaced on an ad hoc basis since. Voltage levels of the medium
voltage (MV) distribution lines are often too low, such as 6 kilovolt kV) for modern utility designs,
and  these  will  all  be  upgraded  and  standardized  at  22  kV  for  the  new  systems.  Distribution

nontechnical. The only practical way to reduce losses and to supply future growth is to replace
these old distribution systems completely, which will be done under the Project.

For  Banlung,  however,  the  existing  distribution  system  was  constructed  in  1993  and  is

still in relatively good condition, and only expansion of this system is required. The high losses
in  Banlung  are  due  mostly  to  nontechnical  losses,  and  a  change  in  local  management  is

8.
